headline: Spicy Shrimp and Grits
description: Quick and easy! This one will be loved by the whole family; it is a constant favorite in my house!
name: Spicy Shrimp and Grits
recipeIngredient: 1 pound peeled and deveined small shrimp
1 (10 ounce) can diced tomatoes and green chilies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x12 inch baking dish.

Bring chicken broth and salt to a boil in a large saucepan over high heat. Stir in the grits, return to a simmer, then reduce heat to medium-low, and continue cooking for 20 minutes, stirring frequently.

Meanwhile, melt the margarine in a skillet over medium heat. Stir in the green onions, green pepper, and garlic; cook until the peppers have softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the shrimp, and cook until they begin to firm.

Stir the Monterey Jack cheese, 3/4 cup Cheddar cheese, shrimp and vegetable mixture, canned tomatoes, and black pepper into the grits; pour into prepared baking dish and sprinkle with remaining 1/4 cup Cheddar cheese.
Bake in preheated oven until the cheese is bubbly and beginning to brown, 30 to 45 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Might add some crushed red pepper flakes for a little more spice.

Great recipe. One of the few I've seen without milk or heavy cream, so my lactose intolerant husband can eat it! I used vegan cheese and a whole can of Rotel (oops!), and added bacon. I think it would be good with quinoa or polenta, it just wouldn't be shrimp and GRITS, it would be shrimp and quinoa! Grits, polenta (cornmeal), and quinoa are all good, but definitely different.
It is simpler and quicker than other shrimp and grits recipes, but it works! I will be making it again.

A weekly meal. The only thing I did different was used cups Better Than Bouillon fish base and boiled up the shrimp shells and used 2 cups of that instead of 4 cups chicken stock when making the grits. Really good!

Absolutely none
It was delicious
This is a staple for my grits loving husband. The only change I make is to use half milk instead of all broth and the grits come out much creamier.

Love this version of shrimp and grits. Only change I made was putting the grits snd cheese mixture into the cast iron skillet in which I cooked the veggies and shrimp. Added the tomatoes and cheese grits. Turned out beautifully and I saved a pan from clean up. Will definitely be making this again!!
everyone loved this. I didn't have Jack Cheese, so I used Havarti. would have probably been even better if I did have Jack (if that's possible).

We are not fans of grits in their "naked" form, but these were loaded with flavor. Used 4 cups of water and 3 T of Knorr chicken granules (no additional salt) to cook quick grits for 20 minutes (even though the package directions stated differently) stirring frequently on simmer. Had most of the ingredients on hand, but used up 1/2 bag of shredded swiss & Guerye cheese + cheddar on the top. I did press excess liquid out of Rotel tomatoes and only had three green onions. Used 1# of med shrimp...no complaints. Poured into a pie plate coated with clarified butter (ghee). Baked in center of oven, turned broiler on for last few minutes to brown the top. Be careful with this step if your casserole dish is not broiler-proof. A definite do-over.
This is an excellent recipe and very easy to make. Like most reviews, I took out one cup of the chicken broth and used Rotel. This one is a keeper!
Added smoked sausage and instead of green onions used yellow onions. Needs Cajun seasoning
Loved this recipe! Very good frozen and reheated too!
I skipped the oven, and substituted for maple sausage links, which i diced into bite size pieces. And because I was out of chiles.. I added Cumin. Man o day was this good!
Underwhelmed. I expected this to be great based on the reviews. It seemed to be missing something in the flavor.

I substituted half the tomatoes with fire-roasted tomatoes and used corn grits instead of regular grits (not to be mistaken for cornmeal. That would be wrong). And, it was delish!!!!! I’be always loved this as a breakfast side as brunch but never made it. Now, with all the peppers and tomatoes, it can be served any time as a side. Loved it!

I really like this recipe. I use the mild diced tomatoes with chilies as my husband not crazy about really spicy things. Also I lessen the cheese and skip the baking step and it’s delicious!!! Thank you for the recipe!
Made it as written and it was great!
I have made this recipe for years and every time I serve it I am ask for the recipe. I always use Rotel and I add smoked sausage . These are the only changes I make, comes out perfect every time.

very tasty, very easy. I made it as written. we liked our very much but on our next try we will spice it up just a bit more, plus a few more shrimp. 
thanks

Made this for the first time last night, and it was an instant hit with our family. I eliminated the chilies because no one in my family does well with spicy foods. Otherwise, do what the recipe says and you'll have a successful dinner!
Simple, easy, very tasty.
Simple, easy, very tasty.
Loved it. We added the Sriracha after we made everything to give it extra spice and so our kids could eat it too and it was just as good!
I used pepper jack and added 1/2 tsp Cajun seasoning, reduced the salt by half. Everything else was according to the recipe. OMG SOOOO GOOD!

We loved it! I didn't change anything, and try not to when I 1st try a recipe. I did use a 2 lb bag of shrimp, because that's what I had, and used a mixed 2 cup bag of shredded cheddar and jack cheese for convenience. Next time I might bake it in individual ramekins, to make portioning easier, and I think it would make for a nice presentation, but that's the only thing I might change. It looked great coming out of the oven, but kinda blah on the plate. I served it with a salad, so it was a nice simple dinner. I like having the 30 minutes of bake time to make the salad. It looked so good coming out of the oven I texted a pic to my friends to torture them "look what we're having for dinner."
This recipe is absolutely delicious!You will not find any better in a restaurant.No changes necessary other than some creole seasoning if you wish to spice it up a bit.

Super yummy. Did a little less black pepper, replacing with a dash or two of cayenne pepper. My grits were "old-fashioned," not "quick," and the container reads a ratio of water to grits of 4 cups to 1 cup, so I was able to follow the recipe exactly and it worked great.
My first time making shrimp and grits as a dish. This recipe drew me in and it was an absolute hit!!!! Thank you!!!
I love this recipe! I add andouille sausage.

Following the advice of others who tried this recipe, I used 3 cups of reduced sodium chicken broth instead of 4. I did not drain the tomatoes & green chilies since I reduced the broth. I used 1/2 tsp Creole seasoning vs 1 tsp salt. The finished product was a little runny with the first serving, but appears to be thicker now that it has had a chance to cool. I think it will reheat nicely also.

Have made it many times and use different cheeses such as gouda, colby jack, monteray jack, and used pepper jack (only used pepper jack once, It was way too spicy.) I also substitute 2 cups of half and half for 2 cups of the chicken broth ( this makes it creamier). I put 1 lb. of cooked smoked sausage in it to.

Absolutely delicious... and EASY! Sure, it's a slightly time-consuming recipe, but the steps and instructions are put in extremely simple terms that even a novice cook like myself can follow. I made this for multiple people and wanted it to have a lot of shrimp, so I doubled the amount of shrimp and only increased everything else up to 1.5X more of what the original recipe called for. The only substitution I made was for the chicken broth because I prefer vegetable, but it didn't (or shouldn't) impact the taste as much due to the strong flavors in all the other ingredients. Definitely a top recipe in my books and will be making it again soon!

I made this without the shrimp because someone else made shrimp to bring to our party. I also did not have bell peppers in the house, so I added some crushed tomatoes. It was fabulous and I will make it with all the ingredients in the recipe next time!
Wonderful recipe, but came out a little runny. Next time I'll drain the diced tomatoes and add a little less water to the grits. Overall, a great recipe.
My family loves this recipe! I have made it many times.

VERY good! This is my husband's favorite meal so I decided to make this for his birthday. It was a huge hit & the best he has ever had (or so he says lol). However, this won't be something I'll be making a ton. I was a little surprised at how time consuming this was. I even cut up all of my peppers the night before & im glad I did! But overall, it was amazing!!
I had to halve the recipe. I would adjust the seasonings slightly. I would drain the tomatoes. Otherwise, it was great!

I made this as is it written, and it is fantastic. It is great as is. I also have a friend who doesn't do seafood, and I made a smaller dish with grilled chicken bits instead of shrimp. He loves it that way too.

I have made this three times and loved it every time. I followed the recipe as written and we really enjoy this simple dinner. It does have a little heat in it from the tomatoes and chilies. You could use diced canned tomatoes if you wanted to cut the heat.

This was amazing! Made a few changes based on reviews:

-3c stock instead of 4 
-Added one additional tbsp butter
-Left out the salt
-Used Rotel (drained before adding)
-Seasoned with a good amount of Cajun seasoning
Easy to make. Turned out delish!!

This was good! I'm not a huge grits fan, but I made it for someone who does. He had thirds! The texture seemed fine to me, but he said it was a little runnier than he expected. I used the full four cups of stock and drained the tomatoes. I also added some Old Bay, some habanero and 1/2 lean turkey sausage (I needed to use it up). I'd definitely make again.
This is one of my favorite recipes!
My family loves this recipe!
Added andouille to the shrimp, and it came out great.
so delicious! I added turkey sausage too and it was SO good.
Loved it!!!! Would not change a thing.
We just made them for the family & was a hit. Even the 3 grandsons who don't like grits. They wanted more. We used Rotel mild tomatoes & chilies & still had a kick. Will make again next week.

I looked high and low for a good Shrimp and Grits recipe. This was easy and SO GREAT! I do not add salt. I drain the rotel, and add Creole Seasonong. I have made it several times and have loved it every time.
I do have to agree that corn meal is NOTHING like grits! You can find grits on the breakfast isle of any grocery store. Also, baking it fuses those flavors to perfection.

I made a lot of changes given what I had on hand: shrimp, bell pepper, green onion, canned tomatoes and chiles, cheese, frozen brown rice. So I just skipped steps 1 and 2 and made the brown rice (microwave). Cooked the pepper, onions, and garlic as directed; added shrimp, tomatoes, rice, and 3/4 cup shredded jack cheese. Sprinkled with grated parmesan. Baked in a 8x8 dish for 25 minutes. Delicious (and hearty for a shrimp dish)!

Read all of the reviews. Decided to keep recipe as it was, except did drain the tomatoes. When first removed from oven, it does look like too much broth, or soupy grits. But, after letting it stand, or rest for about 8-10 minutes, it was perfect.
Favorite for all!

Absolutely the best shrimp and grits recipe out there! I've never altered the recipe. It's good to note if using quick cooking grits, use 3 cups of broth to one cup of grits or if using old fashioned grits, use 4 cups of broth to one cup of grits. Quick cooking grits are already cooked done a bit and don't need as much liquid as old fashioned. Thanks for sharing William!!
LOVED IT! Super-easy and very flavorful!! Very creamy and decadent. Highly recommend Rotel tomatoes with green chile--they actually have quite a good kick to them. Thank you!

I would give this only 3 stars if you eat it right after you make it. It was a little bland for my taste. If you let the dish sit in the fridge for a day (or better, yet, two) before you eat it, then it is a four-star dish...maybe almost five stars. It was better if you lightly season the shrimp with Tony's (or other brand) seafood seasoning before cooking, too. This is now my go-to recipe for shrimp & grits that I make the day before I'm going to eat it. I also left out the salt, as the broth is salty enough already.
Whole family loved it! Made the recipe as stated, except used two pounds of shrimp instead of one.

We loved this. I followed the recipe exactly as written, with the one exception of skipping the added salt. When it came out of the oven, it did indeed seem surprisingly runny (even though I drained the Rotel tomatoes), but we found it to just be creamy when ladled into the low bowls we like to use, and as the dish sat waiting on our second helpings, it absorbed the liquid. I don't think I'll change a thing next time. We loved it.

This was so good!! Family loved it! Only made a few changes based on reviews and what I had in my pantry and on hand. Used a red bell pepper instead of green, used only 3 cups of low sodium chicken broth, plus drained tomatoes and used that liquid in addition to broth for grits. Cooked grits 20 minutes and in last few minutes added a splash of heavy cream to ensure rich creamy texture. Added andouille sausage as well as creole seasoned shrimp. Used pepper jack cheese and sharp cheddar but did not add cheese on top. Baked for 30 minutes. Let it rest for 10 minutes and then served with a fruit salad and crusty hot bread. Sprinkled with chives when serving. First bite and everyone said, this is on the make again and again list!!!
We grilled the shrimp instead and didn't cook it in the oven. We did the grits as per recipe and layered the shrimp on top. It was very good.
Great Family Recipe!! easy to adjust, low prep and Super Happy Family. Thank You :)
So yummy, and very easy to make! Totally manageable for a weeknight meal. I like to reserve some of the green onion to sprinkle on top as a garnish after the dish is finished baking.

These were good. I didn't have monterey jack cheese on hand, but used processed cheese cube instead. I also used a can of diced tomatoes with garlic and onions instead of the ones with green chiles. I seasoned my shrimp with garlic powder, cajun spice, lemon zest, and cayenne pepper to get the spice effect. It all came out really good.

Wow! Being New Englanders, my family and I have never really thought to eat grits. After a recent trip to the South where I ate grits for the first time (at a Waffle House, of course!), I was inspired to make this. My two kids devoured this dish - practically licked the bowl clean! And my son usually doesn't like casseroles or things mixed together! I followed the recipe completely except that I didn't have the canned tomatoes so I used medium salsa, which I scooped out using a fork so that I didn't get too much liquid. Thanks, William! I'll be making this again!
Had to make this for three different groups of people - within a month. This is my quick go-to recipe that everyone absolutely loves. Easy to make and way too tasty to be true!
This was amazing. Even my kids couldn't get enough.

I cut the recipe in half and only adjusted from the reviews and my taste. I didn't add garlic as its not a flavor that I like and no salt because of my health but followed the rest. I did enjoy the flavor, but I think this will be the only time that I make this recipe.
very good, added Cajun seasoning as many recommended.
We haven't tried this yet, but Jenny has and recommended it to me.
Spicy, but so easy and full of flavor!

I've made a lot of Shrimp and Grits but never "casserole style" until I read the reviews and decided to try this recipe last night. It wasn't as visually appealing as the composed version, but was FAR better than I expected and I'll definitely make it again! Using what I had on hand, I slivered half a yellow onion and subbed it for the scallions, and added two fresh diced jalapenos. I drained the RoTel into a glass measuring cup and then added the broth...I actually used leftover seafood stock and the flavor was fantastic. I was afraid that baking for 40 minutes would make the shrimp rubbery but it didn't. The end result was creamy (not soupy) and I served it in shallow pasta bowls, topped with fresh chopped flat leaf parsley. Delicious comfort food that's not too heavy -- a perfect weeknight meal!

Fantastic depth of flavor for minimal effort. I tossed in a cup of baby spinach to add leafy greens to the mix, which worked perfectly. Gluten free yumminess and a definite repeat menu item in Coach Pete's kitchen. One of the best Internet recipes I have made in years. Pow!
Easy and delicious!!

The best shrimp and grits I have ever had hands down!!!! Very flavorful and I loved all the colors the veggies added. The only change I made was adding andouille sausage, which I felt gave it a hint of spice without overpowering. I thinly sliced four smoked andouille sausages and browned them in a pan, then simply added in with the vegetable mixture. Definitely a keeper recipe for sure!
We thought it was just okay

i cooked this exactly, but used vegetable broth in place of chicken because it was what I had. Everything else was made to the T. We really enjoyed this a lot. By the way, my grits box said 4 cups of water to 1 cup of grits. I drained the tomato and green chili's. It was plenty thick for us.

i cooked this exactly, but used vegetable broth in place of chicken because it was what I had. Everything else was made to the T. We really enjoyed this a lot. By the way, my grits box said 4 cups of water to 1 cup of grits. I drained the tomato and green chili's. It was plenty thick for us.
Wonderful. I made this in triplicate. We ate the first batch tonight. The other two batches I froze before baking. I hope they will work well for "mom's not home" nights.

This recipe is very simple and most delicious! As good as I have had at expensive restaurants. I don't really see a need to bake though. I simply served the cheese grits with the shrimp/veggie sauce pour over top.

Made this for the second time tonight for a book group reading a southern novel. My friends loved it. I'm not quite sure why, but I thought it made a bit more of a flavor statement the first time. I might have used onion rather than scallions, probably more cheddar and less Monterrey jack, and certainly white, rather than black, pepper. That being said, the dish is easy, fast (the quick grits cooked in 5 minutes), delicious and attractive. Tricolor peppers add a nice bit of color. Also, rather than draining the tomatoes and peppers as one reviewer suggested, I drained the shrimp and vegetable mix, instead of pouring that liquid into the grits. The consistency was great.

My in laws loved it, only thing it was soupy and I even drained the rotel.. I also added some creole seasoning to the top and on the shrimp. The shrimp were already cooked from the store and so I only cooked for 10 minutes, didn't want the shrimp overcooked and be chewy.

I didn't use the whole 1 pepper only a portion since it was diced up, looked like too much pepper if you used the whole thing.. just use your judgement
I have never made anything like this before and my southern friends LOVE this recipe. Followed it exactly as written. Thank you

This was great. I will make it again. I only used 3 cups of chicken broth and it did not take 20 minutes to cook the grits, more like 5. Everything else I left the same. Next time might add a little old bay to the mix. Was really good and would def make again. Even my 2 year old enjoyed it!

I was looking for a great shrimp & grits recipe & this delivered! I made the recipe with ingredients/amounts exactly as written, I only changed the presentation. My first southern taste of this dish was served with the shrimp mixture over a layer of grits, so that's how I served it, omitting baking it as my grits were not runny at all as others had mentioned. Enjoy!

I added some turmeric for color and flavor and used snipped sun dried tomatoes so I had a nice thick consistency. I wish I would have added some cayenne pepper as I like my food spicy and the title of this was misleading. also used roasted red peppers from a jar instead of green peppers.
Can be eaten after the combining in saucepan but I like the crust that baking gave it!
Good enough for company or a Pot Luck.
This was good but for as much cheese was in it I thought it would have more flavor. I might add bacon next time and reduce the cheese.

Easy to make gluten- free. We used 1 1/3 cups Bobs Red Mill G-Free Cornmeal instead of quick cooking grits. We also used homemade stock from smoked chicken... The smoke adds a dimension that defies description. Be careful not to over cook the shrimp. Mine were pretty much still raw when I combined everything with the grits and they came out of the oven perfect. I will make this for guests. It's that good.

This is a wonderful recipe! I use this recipe all the time when entertaining. It is easy and delicious! William A put together a must-make.

I made a few adjustments based on reading the comments and what I could find to cut down on prep work for this delicious recipe. 
3 cups of low-sodium chicken broth and I buy the pre-diced pepper mix from Publix (tri-color mix). I also use the Publix Medium frozen peeled, deveined and de-tailed medium shrimp that is roughly 1.5 lbs. I use a spicy Rotel and I would recommend also draining.

Five Stars guaranteed!!!!

First time I ever cooked this. It was excellent. The only alteration I had made was that I added smoked bacon, diced, and sautéed it with the vegetables. I also drained to juice from the can of tomatoes.

I was nervous that this recipe was "too simple" to be good, boy was I wrong! Very tasty dish, my husband exclaimed it was the best thing he has ever tasted! I made some slight modifications, added some old bay and used some parmesean cheese in addition to a bag of shredded. Also, be sure to use a can of Rotell tomatoes, they added a lot of flavor. My grits were a tad runny, so next time I will thicken them up a bit. YUMMY!!
Tasty but I felt like I was eating shrimp and grits smothered in queso.Too cheesy for me.
wonderful my family loved it

This recipe was amazing! I like things pretty spicy so I kicked up the recipe on spicyness a bit since I wasn't cooking for my kids. First time I have ever made shrimp or grits!!! I omitted the salt since chicken broth already has enough salty flavor. I also used a 1/2 white onion instead of green onion since I forgot the green onion at the store. I added some polska kielbasa sausage as well. I used pepperjack instead of monterey jack and for the diced tomatoes and green chilis I used the Rotell HOT with habaneros. This was the best shrimp and grits that I have ever had... and my boyfriend agreed!
Terrible. Stay with a traditional recipe rather than this casserole nightmare version.
I found this to be really runny.

Great dish! I did make several changes after reading the other reviews. I used 3 cups of broth to 1 cup of grits, omitted the salt, used butter instead of margarine, increased garlic to 4 cloves, drained the tomatoes and chilies, added a touch of real bacon bits, and a touch of hot sauce for an extra added kick. No need to bake as this is ready to serve over the cooked grits! This is a definitely a keeper.
Very tasty! Loved it! Not 'traditional' shrimp and grits but a nice casserole.
I have always sworn that I HATE grits but this is phenomenal! I am not a true southerner but have lived here 15 years. Make sure to add bacon
I omitted the salt and drained the rotel as some other reviewers suggested. I also added a tablespoon of cajun spice to the shrimp as I sauted. This was excellent!

My husband and I love this recipe. It is a great comfort food on a chilly night. I use the shrimp already peeled and deveined for convenience. The only change I've made is to drain the can of chiles/tomatoes (Rotel) as it will make it way too juicy. And I add a lot more cheese. Yummy!

This turned out terribly for me. This ended up very watery when I took it out of the oven for 45 minutes. Although, when I took it out of the oven and put it on the stove with corn starch to thicken it, the flavor was wonderful. I will not put this in the oven next time.
